hey @alvinhom , pinot does create and use inverted index for dimensional filtering, we use roaring bitmap for inverted index compression. Using and creating Inverted index is configurable on a per column basis, sometimes simply sorting the date on a column which is always filtered upon is good enough to achieve fast query response times, in which case we can avoid using inverted index to filter on other columns, this helps us to server more data off of ram. 

Hope that helps, Also the google groups should be up soon. 

Regards
Dhaval
thank you @uce for letting us know.. its been fixed.

Adding to what Dhaval said, there  is a way to configure a column
as the leading key. For example, if you have userData, userId can be the
leading key. We create a different type of index (sorted index) for the
leading keys and we have seen that this improves the performance
significantly (especially when queries contain filters on this column)

Thanks for pointing out the missing documentation. We will add it.

thanks,
Kishore G

It would seem that Maven runs out of heap space. Can you try setting MAVEN_OPTS to give it more heap space? Running this before doing `mvn -DskipTests install` should work:

``` bash
export MAVEN_OPTS="-Xmx1G"
```

The issue with hardcoded "localhost" has now been resolved.

Currently, the realtime consumption in Pinot uses the high level consumer which leads to the behavior you're seeing.

If you want to create two servers that consume from Kafka, each of them should get their own consumer group ID so that they each get all of the data; since the realtime segment boundaries include offsets, all replicas of the realtime segments should contain the same data, so a server node that crashes does not change the query results.

This is not ideal and it's on our roadmap to improve Kafka consumption.

What happens if one of the servers crashes (the server process itself), I
understand that the second server will consume 100% of the messages while
the second server is down (I can see that the broker query returns about
half of the documets numbers in this case), but how can I add the second
server again (if at all) in order to restore the original setup ?

There are two scenarios,

#1. adding a new server

In this case, the new server will start handling 1/2 of the total msgs. I
think, there is a need to tag the new machine with the same name as the old
one. I know there is an api for this buts its probably not documented. (we
will provide a command to do this).

#.Bringing the failed server back up

In this case, the messages will again be distributed equally among the two
nodes. There is no need to make any additional modifications to the tag as
in previous case.

In general, you want to use have multiple replicas to handle failures.

Broker: Have more than one broker will provide you fault tolerance. The
request can be forwarded to any live broker.

Controller: Simply start multiple controllers, there is leader election
among the controllers and only one controller will manage the cluster. If
the leader fails, a new leader is elected and it starts managing the
cluster.

Server: Here when you create a resource, you specify the number of replicas
needed for each segment. Typically we use 3 replicas in our deployment. In
case of failure, broker automatically detects the failures and routes the
queries to live servers.

Hope this helps.

Thanks,
Kishore G

Thank you for your answers,
Can you please be more specific about the how server vs replicas work?
I'm taking the scenario of real-time consumption and storing same table on multiple servers.

Are replicas created and queried by the server process or using the controllers ?
I'm asking that because I want to be sure that I know how to deal with potential failures.

A server process dumps its segment data to the hard disk (I assume that we use 3 replicas per segment), and this data is read when query is received.
If suddenly the server process stopped (due to an exception memory error etc.) - the stored data of the replicas isn't reachable anymore, right ? It's not ever relevant that the data is replicated, because the process which is responsible for reading the data is down.
Let's say I re-start the same failed server process again. Will the old replicated data will be available as soon as the new server process is up ? Will it continue to add new data to the old replicas, or will create new replicas and the old (pre-failure) data will be lost?

Thank you again. Pinot is an exciting project and I really want to understand how to use it in my case.

P.S. if there's some technologies that Pinot is build on and will answer my questions I'd be happy to read about it.
This issue had resolved  in commit c875cc0

If there is a limited number of servers relative to ZK nodes, it could be the case that this exhausts the limit of ZK connections from a single node. The default value for `maxClientCnxns` in ZK is 10, so if there is only one ZK host and all the cluster is running on one machine, it could prevent the kafka client from connecting to zk.
When pinot build segment, it store the dicId for metric field instead of value.

When writing a Grafana datasource, we can send any query that would produce a suitable result set. I don't need the query to look exactly like the InfluxDB query.  An equivalent query written with different syntax would work perfectly fine.  If there is a way to query Pinot already to do this I just need an example query as I couldn't find a reasonable way to do it given the PQL documentation.  What we fundamentally need is a way to get results that are grouped by regular time intervals such that they can be plotted as a time series chart.

In some instances we would want to average the grouped data points, for others we would want the sum or percentiles.

We don't support it right now, but we can add support for it. Would something like `select timebucket(timeColumn, '5m') as time, avg(metric) from ... group by time` work?

I'll take a look at Grafana to see how we can support your use cases in Pinot. Are all the types of queries that you foresee all aggregations on time buckets or would you need other special operators/functions (eg. moving averages, etc.)?

Hi @jfim,

Yes, that looks reasonable. I'm not aware of any current needs for moving averages.

For Grafana, we need essentially need is a query that we can use to implement:

```
query(table, aggregations, from, to, interval);
```

So following your PQL example, that might be something like:

```
SELECT timebucket(timestamp, '5m') as time avg(metric) FROM table WHERE timestamp BETWEEN x AND y GROUP BY time
```

I'm not sure if `1h` time buckets are hour aligned or not.  E.g. can hour buckets be for `[1:36-2:36)`, `[2:36-3:36)`, ... or just for `[1:00-2:00)`, `[2:00-3:00)`?

Grafana supports auto-refresh of time series charts in the UI.  It does this by automatically making additional queries to the datasource. E.g.:

```
SELECT ... WHERE timestamp BETWEEN fromTime AND toTime ... # Initial query 
SELECT ... WHERE timestamp BETWEEN toTime AND refreshTime1 ... # auto-refresh 1
SELECT ... WHERE timestamp BETWEEN refreshTime1 AND refreshTime2 ... # auto-refresh 2
...
```

And Grafana assumes that these queries will not overlap. I believe Grafana also makes sure the time intervals it asks for are sized and aligned in a reasonable way.  Eg. It might ask for 5m intervals for the initial query and then for 30s intervals after that.

If you're curious.  Here's a (not yet working) Grafana pinot datasource:

https://github.com/coursera/grafana/tree/pinot-datasource/public/app/plugins/datasource/pinot

It's based on the InfluxDB datasource.  The main thing it's missing is the query we've been discussing.  Once supported, I would simply modify this:

https://github.com/coursera/grafana/blob/pinot-datasource/public/app/plugins/datasource/pinot/queryBuilder.js#L60

And we'd have basic Grafana support.

We could probably have a third optional parameter for time bucketing that chooses the reference start point for the buckets.

I'll have to come up with a good design for this. Out of curiosity, how does Grafana handle standard/daylight savings time or irregular time intervals (months with various lengths/bissextile years)?

@jfim I've only played around with Grafana for about a day.  Here's what I was able to find:

In most of the dropdowns they only support second, minute, hour and day. But it does look like they have support for month and year: http://docs.grafana.org/reference/timerange/ . I couldn't find any details on how exactly those work.

I'm planning to provide timeseries to Grafana in UTC (avoiding daylight savings confusion).  It looks like Grafana has at least basic support for taking UTC data and rendering graphs in the viewers locale.  But that feature does seem to have caused issues in the past (https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/143, https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/277, https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/13).  Regardless, UTC is the way to go.

For missing data,  Grafana still expects a data point for each time interval that was requsted, but the data value can be "null" (in JSON) in which case Grafana supports a couple options: "connected", "null", and "null as zero".  I believe "connected" means to linear interpolate between the last point before the gap to the first point after the gap (not sure what happens if the gap is at the start or end).  And I believe "null" just means leave the gap in the rendered UI.  The default it "connected".
